div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p:
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA,
MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe
for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every
Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for
Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to
LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN,
MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and
SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table
wine free.

Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at
Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other
Tourist Agency.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p:
The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between
Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to
Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation
for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry
proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent
Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to
Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor,
Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to
Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque)
begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the
Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the
scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus
in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.

Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook
& Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY,
General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
Monday, DEC. 16, 1907.
A GERMAN VIEW OF AMERICA.
Two books on America have recently appear-
éd in German: “Americana,” by Karl Lam-
precht, the distinguished jurist of the Univer-
sity of Leipzig, an unpretentious volame by
Ludwig Fulda, the poet and novelist. This is
“the sympathetic review of a witty and equally
sharp-eyed critic, upon whom the friendly sum
shone on the first day of his arrival in New
York, and continued to shine, with rare excep-
tions, until bis reluctant departure for Europe.
Fulda,” says the New York “Nation,” “came
to America with a free and receptive mind, .
and yielded himself completely to whatever
impressions his‘environment should make......
“That which most exceeds all expectations
of the author, however, is the extent.of popu-
Jar education in America, and our systems of
public and higher instruction. Every one here
jis hungry to learn, reading is more general
than in any other country,and libraries surpass
in number and practical organisation, as well
as sometimes in magnificent buildings, anyth-
ing- known abroad. ‘Every American, from
millionaire to shoeblack, and from professor to
schoolboy, is a fanatical newspaper reader,’
because of and notwithstanding ‘the ‘horrible
headlines,’ This fact may account for the im-
portunate artists and women reporters, who
more than once insisted on interviewing him
at his morning toilet,‘in the name of the news-
paper, of course’ ; and for the piracy of foreign
literature, calling for revision of the American
copyright laws. f | |
“Fulda observes with natural satisfaction the
wide study of German by Americans He at-
tends classes and chapel, lectures and dines at
colleges for women, and-is delighted with the
opportunity afforded the girls in America for
advanced study, regarding their way: of living
and preparing for the duties of life superior to
that of the average young woman in Germany
dancing away herexistence. He is inclined to
believe that Schiller’s exhortation, ‘Ehret die
Frauen |’ is observed by Germans rather in
theory than in practice, more in words than in
deeds. He prefers coeducation to the” habit
abroad of separating the sexes so long, praises
the free relations between American professors
and their students, and has a good word’
generally for student life among our young
men, with their concerts and student plays.He .
feels a satisfactionin the absence of scarred
and bloated faces, and holds that even the ex-
cesses of athletics are better than duel and the
‘Mensar.’
“He finds no genuine American art, notwith-
standing a popular artistic feeling, museums,
and academies ; and he thinks that individual,
creative art is wanting because the American,
alive to decorate his house, has not yet learned
to adorn his life with art. Hard work, elaborate
not perceived how great a force for good the
theatre in right hands. may become, and no
American philanthropist has endowed. the
stage. In condemning the oft-repeated per-
formance of the same play, Fulda errs in say-
ing that Jefferson played the one role all his
life."

div.head: Local and General
div.p:
Cholera at Mecoa.
An_ isolated case of cholera is reported from Mecca.
Now Quay Appointment.
» Mohamed Effendi Khatta, Ministry of Just: ice, has been appointed Superintendent of the Alexandria quays.
The Coldstream Cuarde.
The annual sports of the 3rd Battalion Coldstream Guards will be held on the Slade ground, Abbassia, on Thursday next.
There aré now 19 cases of plagne under treatment, One case has been discharged cured and one has ended fatally at: Alexandria.
The Coast ‘Guards Administration -seized 106 kilos and 850 grammes of hasheesh in the Port Said’ harbour on the 12th inst. this being the second seizure made at Port Said within the fortnight.

A Council of Ministers will be heldthis week, and the report of the special water commission will be one of the subjects submitted to the Council. We understanéthat this report is in every way a favourable one.

The first small dance of the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, will be held next Saturday. Tables for dinner and supper should be booked early as numerous, orders haye already been given. The Old Rugbeian Dinner will also be held at the Savoy on the same evening.

Members Of the Cairo Scientific Society are invited to inspect the Rodah Bridge by invita- tion of Mr. A. J: Knowles, on Thursday next. A paper will be read before the Society by Mr. Knowles, at a later date, describing * the construction of the Bridge.

The sale of work of the Young Women’s Christian Association, Cairo, which will be opened at 3.30 p.m. to-morrow by Lady Gorst at the Semiramis Hotel, will be re-opened at the same hour on the following day by Lady Blanche Smith at-Connaught House;

Between January 1 and December 1.291,617 tons of coal were imported into Egypt, of which 711,207 tons wete Welsh, 158,579 12 * Noweastle, 186,149 Yorkshire, 100,080 Scotch and 135,602 other qualities. During the corres- ponding period of last year the imports totalled 1,217,384:

The Criminal Court of Alexandria which met-on the 14th inst. under the presidency of Judge- Mohamed Bey Said, Councillor to the Court of Appeal,.have sentenced Akeel Saad, Saad Ahmed, and *Abnbaker Massad, who murdered the Omdeh of Zarka village, to im prisonment with hard labour for life.

Maurice E. Bandmann has arranged for his London Comedy Company.to appear for two weeks at the Khedivial Opera House, Cairo, in the latter part of April and beginning of May next. The company has carried every- thing before it during their eighteen months -tour in India and the Far East. While in Cairo they will give the following popular London successes :— “Raffles,” “His House in Order,” ‘The Walls of Jericho,’ “The Christ- ian.” ‘The Morals of Marcus,” “John Glade's Honour,” “Che Admirable Crichton,” ‘Peter's Mother,” “Old Heidelberg,” “Sherlock Holm- es,” “The Earl of Pawtucket,” and “Sunday.” The repertoire is certainly an excellent one and seding that the company 1s carrying some fifty tons of scenery we are likely to see each piece staged in the same elaborate mauner as in London.

div.head: Alexandria Conservatoire of music
div.p: The fifth annual entertainment given by the } pupils of the above flourishing institution took place on Saturday in the Lifontr concert hall, and’ attracted*a large and’ fashionable “audience. Most ofthe items showed a dec idedl improvement on last year's. pe ‘rformance, which was more particnlarly marked in the individual numbers. The choruses might be much more forcibly. rendered. appeared to be an absence of any attempt at accentuate the light and shade which 1s 80 necessary in order to produce the’ effects in- tended in such achorosas Verdi's “I Profughi Scozzesi” trom Macbeth.

The same remark applies to the chorus “‘La Primavera” in*the sécond part. The soprano solo in this, Azzarelli, whose perfofmance was rather spoil- ed, however, by an evident nervousness. In Mayerbeer’s romance “Sic Vendicata’ Prof, Gianni Galletti put forward one -of his best pupils in Sig. D.Lambridis,who has a fine yoice. of excellent.quality and his tasteful rendering was much appreciated. Schumann’s duet “for soprano and tenor “La Danza” was pleasingly he instrumental numbers. were particularly good. Sig. Perdichidis and ig. R.. Scinica gave violin, solos in @ manner which was most comméndable. Messtfs. Te: and J. Papasian are worthy of more than passing notice: each worked hard and contributed considerably to thé suecess of the enter- tainment. We congratulate. Signore. Gianni Galletti. Lama, Colella, Romeo, and Onesti, on the excellent progress made by the pupils.

div.head: Companies in Egypt
div.p: SUPREME COURT'S DECISIONS.

Judge:Cator in the Supreme British Con- sular Court~delivered judgment this morning on the two appeals of the Bourse and Banking Company Ltd against the judgments of the Consular Court given on the 20th November last. The Appeal Court dismissed both appeals and ordered the Bourse and Banking Company to pay the costs in the Court below and on the appeals.

These decision of the Supreme Court to up- hold the judgments of the lower Court, given on the 20th ulto., are of great importance as all thie numérous limited liabilities companies, registered under the companies Acts, «whose sphere of operations are in Egypt, are now declared to be amenable to the jurisdiction of the British Consular Courts, whether their boards are composed of subjects of foreign Powers or not. In the one case an application was made by an English shareholder of the Bourse and Banking Company of Egypt Limited, represented by Mr. Gooding for the removal of the liquidator, appointed at the meeting of the shareholders and the appointment of a liquidatornominated by the Court. Mr. Devon- shire, who represented the company contended that the court had (4) no jurisdiction onder section 12 of the Order in Council, (2) no jurisdiction in that the circumstances do not admit of same under section 107 of the Order unless, under section 167, the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs should make an order covering a case where the circumstances do not permit.

The Court held that the question at issue fell Within jurisdiction as the plaintiff isa British subject and the defendant compuny of the same nationality,whereby the Mixed Courts could have no jurisdiction. Council for the defence appealed to the Supreme Court, which has now decided that the Court had jurisdiction.

In the second case, the plaintiff, an English shareholder in the same company, represented by Mr. Reginald Silley, brought an action on the tollowing grounds. The plaintiff had been allotted 200 shares in the Company which he sold at a premium of #5. Subsequently, on the announcement that the bearer warrants were ready, plaintiff applied through the Anglo- Egyptian Bank for delivery of same. He was requested by the company to sign a form in accordance with the regulations of the Alexandria Bourse, or otherwise the company would not make the delivery. The plaintiff filled up the form, expunging the words “according to the Alexandria Bourse require- ments.” Mr. Silley sabmitted that such con- dition in the form was unfair and interfered with ‘the rights of private contract and, therefore, the company is improperly retaining the warrants. Mr. Devonshire, for the company contended that art. 47 of the company’s sta- tutes fully empowered the directors to de- termine the conditions upon which* the bearer warrants should be issued and to settle the form of application for the same. The. lower Court held that the directors were not justified in attaching such condition and gaye judg- ment for the plaintiff for the delivery of the warrants or £200 and costs. The Bourse and Banking Company, appealed against this decision, but, as already announ- ced, the Supreme Court dismissed the appeai.
The full bearings of these decisions will be considered in another issue.

Sir-Eldon Gorst was received in audience by the Khedive on Saturday morning and his Highness also granted audicaces to Lemaire Bey. Crookshank Pasha, Mr. Pacliano, Rouma- nian Consul General, Mr. Smyrnoff, Russian Diplomatic Agent, ‘who introduced Prince Mi- chael Gortchacoff, Chevalier Serra, Italian acting Diplomatic Agent, who introduced Mr, Pan] Brenna, Count Bernsdorff, German Diplo- matic Agent, Dr. von Campe and Mattre Carton de Wiart.
‘DISTINGUISHED PASSENGERS. (FROM uUR OWN CORRESPONDENT. )

Beyrout, December 12. The Khedivial Mailliner S.8. “Tantah’ arrived yesterday from Constantinople with a contin- gent of pilgrims for Mecca among whom were the following distinguished personages: the mother of the present Shah of Persia, Sultan Mobam- med Ali, and his brother Prince Nasreddine Mirza, with a large retinue of Ulemas etc. The Prince is only eleven~ years of age and is said to be endowed with remarkable intelligence. After the official visits to the Seraglio and the Per- sian Consulate General, his Highness stopped: with his mother as honoured guests at the Vali’s residence for the night and then proceeded by the some boat next day toCaiffa,where they are to take the Hedjaz Railway for the sacred towns. The S;. “Tantah” took from Beyrout 315 pilgrims.

div.head: Egyptian Politics
div.p: The formation of an. Egyptian, Repebliean Nationalist party is still exciting a good deal of discussion, for the demand for thé’ immedia te constitution of an’ antonomous’ automatic, and independent republic of Egypt has at- tracted a good deal of notice. A vernacular contemporary remarks :—

It appears now that. the leader of this. new movement is an editor. who acted as assistant and counsellor to thesupposed leader. of the Egyptian Liberals. Well, liberalism bas in many ¢éases led to republicanism and even to socialism, and we are .in the same boat with other nations. But who is the candidate for the presidency according to present arran- gements?

“Al Watan,” the Coptic Cairo organ, in’a notice of the Coptic party, says :— ~ The coptic party was given® the death blow by the refusal of “Al-Watan” to” work=for ite constructions; Yet some:individuals talk ofits coming formation and say that it will not insiat upon the public useof the ancient Coptic language as the basis-of its political mission.

The general assembly of the active-members of the National Party will take place atthe “Lewa” office on Friday the 27th. inst) in order to select. the committee of direction: and to approve the statutes. “Our Direetor,” says the “Egyptian Standard,” “will deliver-an im« portant political discourse. on the-occasion.”

A Cairo correspondent writes :— Great indignation has been aroused among. the various political parties in Cairo atthe, news that Abdul Razik Pasha has had a mani-, festo published in the London “Standard,” outlining the aims of the Party of the People. The other parties of “‘Nationalistic” proclivities, recognise that the handful of political busy- bodies in England, who take an interest.in, Egypt, will soon be so confased as to the state of affairs here that they will be quite unable to know which ‘Party’ topatronise. The Moderate Nationalists and the Egyptian Liberals have:} each had various maniféstoes published in the, London newspapers and now that the Party of the People has secured a footing in the English; Press, it will be difficult for the Radi¢als to. distinguish one party from the other, especially as they are all, collectively and individually, anathematised by Mustapha Pasha Kamel. The leader of the Nationalist Extremists is very, much chagrined at Abdul Razik Pasha’s in auguration of a forward policy in the London Press, for not only hus he lost the’ patronage of Mr. Robertson, M:P.~ and’ Aborigines Pro- tection Society, but he has seen his influence in England undermined by the Moderates and the recent’ foundation of the party of the Constitutional Reformers-has: still further in- creased his vexation. NoW.even the Party of the People, which he always affected to despise, has gained a hearing. in Exgland and of eourse every tresh party helps to diminish his in- fluence as the sole and supreme head of the National Movement.

div.head: Bulletin De La Bourse
div.p: Le marché a présenté 1a méme aspect que la semaine passée, c’est-a-dire sans animation et avec unchiffre d’affairesexcessivement restreint. A part quelques échanges insignifiants et clair-. semés en Comptoir, Delta Land et quelques / autres valeurs, on n’a traité quela Khédivial Mail qui a été offerte sur le marché par milliers. Les ordres de venteprovenaient principalement da Caire. Cependant; comme il s’est trouvé des acheteurs pour absorber toutes les offres, le prix, apres avoir fiéchi de ‘1 shelling, est re- montéen cléture 4 20/6 acheteurs, soit en dé- finitive une perte de 6 pence en tout:pour la séance.
La Delta Land, la New-Egyptian, }’Aboukir, la Port Said Salt et la Salt & Soda étaient oftertes.

Quant aux titres dirigeants, ils ont été négli- gés, comme cela ressort de:leur cotation 4 des prix légtrement — inférieurs A ceux de vendredi passé. En vue d’éviter de nouveaux frais d’admi- nistration, un groupe de porteurs de parts Société Egyptienne de la Daira Sanieh de- mande au conseil d’administrafion de «porter & l’ordre du jour de la prochaine assemblée générale annuellé la question de la liquidation | et répartition de l’actif existant. Une pétition dans ce sens, couverte de signatures, va étre -expédiée 4 S.S8. Harari Pacha . qu’on propose comme liquidateur. div.head: Telegrams
div.p: GALES AND RAINS.
SHIPPING DISASTERS.
London, December 14.
” A farious gale has been blowing since yester-
day evening. There have been many wrecks
and loss of life on the South coast. A seven-
masted American schooner has been wrecked
at Scilly and 18 people drowned A _ pinnace
belonging to H.M.S. “Speedwell” was capsized
at Sheerness and 8 men drowned. Cross-Chan-
nel trafic has been interrupted and telegraph
wires are down. Torrential rains have caused
the Thames and.Severn to overflow and large
tracts of land are inundated. Extraordinary
scenes are. witnessed all along the Thames
valley. .( Reuter)
A SENSATIONAL STORY:
SERVANTS AS SPIES.
New York, Deceniber 14.
The newspapers publish” sensational stories
stating that all Japanese servants have been
landed from the battleships of the Pacific fleet
in the Hampton Roads because they were
constantly taking notes. One was detected
noting a new system of guncontrol. (Reuter)
DUMA EX- ee ON TRIAL.
Sr. Peon December 15,
In the treason trial against the Social De-
inocrats, 7 ex-members of the second Duma
have been acquitted and 80 exiled to Siberia
The Socialist group of the Doma tended
violently towands a democratic republic.
(Havas)
Sr. Pererssvra, December 15,
The trial of Socialists, including 37 ex-mem-
bers of the Duma, for treason here has resulted
in most drastic sentences. 80 of the ex-Du-
maites are to be permanently exiled in Siberia,
22 of them receiving, in addition, varions terms
of imprisonment. (Reuter)
THE KAISER’S SENTIMENTS.
-AMSTERDAM, December 14.
The German Emperor, replying to Queen
Wilhelmina’s toast, said that he would stake
his life on the maintenance. of peace between
Germany and Holland. He referred to the
Netherlands as the land where his ancestors
had learned their duty to their country.
(Reuter )
THE DEFENCE POLICY.
MELBOURNE, December 14.
Mouse of Representatives. Mr. Deakin, out-
lining the defence policy of the Government,
said that it was proposed to purchase three
submarines and two destroyers annually for
three years. Military training was to be com-
pulsory for all youths attaining the age of 18.
"He hoped that a national guard of 218,000
trained men wai) ‘be available in eight years.
( Reuter)
‘Lonny, December 14.
The Duke and Duchess of Connanght will
embark at Marseilles on 2nd January: for
Malta. : ( Reuter )
Beri, December 14.
The Reichstag Committee has agree] upon
(Reuter) nings 19 runs for no wickets.
the Polish Bill as amended. -

div.head: THE PERSIAN PARLAMENT.
div.p: Teheran, December 15. The Cabinet resigned yesterday in conse- quence of incidents arising ont ofthe murder of two shop keepers by soldiers, who were im- prisoned bat whose immediats execution was demanded by the relatives of the victims and the Anjumans. A great crowd, partly armed, assembled near the Parliament buildings. The bazaars were closed and ball cartridges were served out tothe Palace quards and garrison The Shah summoned Nizam Sultaneh and Nizam el Malk.

(Later). Parliament has been informed that the ex-Premier and ex-Minister of the Interior have been arrested by order of the Shah The House has demanded an explanation from the Sovereign, refusing to quit the building before & reply was received. The crowd is also wait- ing. It is believed that the Shah is acting on the advice of the reactionary members ( Reuter)

DurBan, December 14. Dini Zulu has started for Durban. Colonel Mackenzie’s troops have returned to Nongoma after marching throngh the disaffect- ed areas. They discovered a number of young Usutu tribesmen with rifles who were missing. (Reuter)
Durpan, December 15. Ten of the principal natives accompanying Dini Zulu have been arrested on suspicion of sedition. (Reuter)

Marnia, December 14. A Jarge column has left to punish the Beni- Snassens.. ~* , (Havas) Oran, December 15. A French column 3,000 strong has moved out of Lalaparmania, operating against the Snassen tribesmen who are posted in the hills, (Reuter)
Tanargr, December 14. Abd el Aziz has given France and Spain the orderto repress contraband of arms in Moroc- an waters, (Havas) T'anarer, December 15. M. Regnault has returned. (Havas)
SALONIKA, December 15. 2,000 Montenegrins have crossed the frontier near Gusinie and massacred the inhabitants of two Albanian villages. ( Reuter)

Sr. Peressnvat Deesibber 15. Important developments are imminent in Finland. General Kaulbars, ex-Governor of Odessa, will be appointed Governor-General and a strong military force is proceeding there, ostensibly for manwuyres. The Government is apparently resolved to crush the revolutionary, organisations. (Reuter)
Sypney, December 14. Cricket. At lurich time Australia’s score was os runs for 2 wickets. (Reuter) Sypyry, December 14. Cricket Australia 300. England second in- (Reuter)

div.head: Austira and Macedonia
div.p: AN IMPORTANT INTERVIEW. Vrewna, December 14. In political cireles great importance is at- tached to the interview to take place to-day between Baron Marshall and Baron d’Aeren- thal concerning Macedonia judiciary question. The Prince of Bulgarie has. visited Baron d’Aerenthal, (Havas)
hisses: ILLE, December 14, Trp cases of plague have been notified here. ( a ee
STORMS IN FRANCE.
Paris, December. 14. Violent storms throughéut France are re ported. (Havas)
Deceuker 15. Senatorial election. Philipot, Republican, has been elected, beating André. (Havas)
KING VICTOR PATRON; | Romer, December 15. The King has become patron of the Italian Anti-Duelling League. (Reuter)

div.head: Headaches and Neuralgia.
div.p: THE EFFICACY OF DR. WILLIAMS’ PINK PILLS.

Mme Octave Mignolet, whose portrait is given herewith, lives in the Rue Longue, Ostend. She suffered trom a variety of ailments, and particularly sick headaches and acute neafalgia, Dr. Williams’ Pink Pills for Pale People had an excellent effect on her nervous system, and now she has ceased to suffer from neuralgia and headaches, and enjoys splendid health.

“I was always in pain,” she writes, “and there never was a night when I could look back and say that I had passed a pleasant day. I was out of gorts and not at all strong. What | ~. ra "| fatiened me more than anything else were sick headaches, which I had almost every day, while sometimes I had neuralgia for weeks at a stretch. My life became insupportable, for I could scarcely get a moment's sleep. I resorted to all sorts of devices to get some rest, but my neuralgia was an obstacle to all my efforts, and the nights passed without my having slept atall Of course, I tried many medicines, but none of them did me any good, until I gave Dr. Williams’ Pink Pills a trial, having.read of their efficacy ina newspaper. These pills cured me, ahd my existence is now quite changed.” The prediliction for sick headaches in the weaker sex is proverbial. Headaches are due to stomech disorder, and when they occur frequently, it is a sign of anemia. It is the ‘|. same with neuralgia, thé continuance of which

div.head: COTTON IN. THE LEVANT.
div.p: (From Ovr Owy CoRRESPONDENT.)

Beyrouth, 9th December. The publication by Reuter’s Agency of the} important intelligence of the final conclusion of details of the Konia Irrigation Scheme has brought once more Asia Minor with its _poli- tical and vast economic possibilities, before the eyes of Europe and will continue to be the chief subject of discussion and comment. A few particulars therefore about the present agricultaral and industrial activities of the outlying regions such as Mersine and’ Adana may not be devoid of particular interest. In a former article ample reference was made to the recent introduction of the perfected methods of steamploughing in connection particularly with cotton cultivation and the following com- plementary notes appear to be necessary. The area under cotton cultivation in Mersine and Adana districts is estimated at about 170,000 acres and the yield ranges between forty and fifty thousand bales of 200 kilogrammes the bale. The Germans seem to have had a long time ago their eye on the cotton culture with its vast possibilities of development and it was German capital that built the first factory for ginning crude cotton and the pressing of bales according tothe system adopted in Egypt. Bales of 250 kilogrammes pressed at this factory have a much smaller volume than bales of 200 kilos, ordinarily pressed, The resulting economy in freight is obvious ‘Thanks to German initiative also the seed of ‘the American ‘quality known as “Upland” and which is in special demand in the New Orleans markets has been introduced first as a trial and is since being gradually vulgarized considering the eminently satisfactory results In the direction of the development of agri- cultural methods on modern lines the English | sales have the largest share of initiative, and most ‘if not all of the various implements lately introduced have come and still come from English firms, notably that of Messrs. John Fowler and Co. Ltd. at Leeds. There are‘ now in use six steamplonghs of which two with single traction and four with double traction, several orders are on the way. There are also 60 thrashing machines, and every year fairly important additions to the existing stock are made. As regards reaping machines they may be counted by hundreds and indeed their use is universal save in the mountainons parts where the primitive scythe still’survives. —

But the field for gigantic enterprise is left for the Germans, and the pent up activity of | . this eminently scientific and industrious nation is destined to manifest itself ina magnificent manner and restore that virgin country to its old glory, with. the additional blessings of modern civilization, when it is likely to become a great centre of productiveness that will count as a factor in the world’s economic problem. The Baghdad railway, a grandiose scheme, is being slowly elaborated and step by step it is nearing the great though distant goal. The Mersine Tarsus Adana Line which is $7 kilo- meters in length has already been bought up by the Germans and two shipments of about 1200 tons of, iron sleepers have lately been discharged by the German Atlas steamers of Bremen, to replace the old and worn out material. This small line is destined to be ultimately linked with the grand trank line which has passed already Eregli and reached Bourgulu which lies within only 160 kilometers of Mersine.

This junction which seems to be inevitable will be either at Adana or Mersine. In the first case the Baghded trunk line will it is said have to pass by Koulek Boughaz round the base of the intervening chain of mountains | and passing the valley join the M.T.A. line at Adana. In the second case the Baghdad line will have to cross the Pass of Dunkelek and join the M.T.A. line at Mersine. In either indicates organic Conkle and poverty of the blood, Dr Willian’ Pick Pills for Pale People| © have a full assortment of ereate rich and pure blood with every dose ;} neW and fashionable goods for the they tonify the nervous system ; and they are| . sovereign against anemia, chlorosis: general season. debility, stomach ills, rheumatism, sick head- aches, and neuralgia.

case the Taurus will have to be traversed and it is here that the greatest material obstacle in the way of the grand scheme lies. The Koulek Boughaz route involves the construction of fewer tunnels but presents on the other hand difficulty of crossing large marshy tracts. The Dunbelek route while involving more costly and difficult tan has the advantage of avoiding these tracts. The plan favoured-by the Turkish Govern. nent would cause the line to pass by Konlek | Boughaz following mére or less closely the actual carriage road which meets the Mersine Tarsous Adana line at Tarsous. The Anatolian Railway. Company. however” prefers. another | Sosa plan lying more in an easterly direction and us A ee ealoulated to bamuch shorter and less costly. , ae The trunk line in that case would follow the valley of Bozant descending through the valley an of Tchakit-Déré directly to Adana. In any case the Koulek Boughaz route would term in- ae other ieee are as Follows :— Ke Sa vy: eee or _—_ ol Mageaby “cana, RuoCherf Pacha, ALEXANDRIA, aleo at ate at Tarsous or rather at the station of Koulek Boughaz about 6 kilometers East of Tarsous and not at Mersine, © Apart from the p0litical interest attaching tothe Baghdad Railway the economic side thereof has incalculable importance, more so as it is bound up with the great Mesopotamian irrigation scheme. The niost indifferent cannot fail to watch with interest” the evdlution of this colossal scheme and we can only hope that the two great sister nations will ultimately find means of conciliating their political and econo- mic interests, and once an agreement is come to, the greatest of modern achievements will unfold themselves to the eyes of the word.
